bcl:text.#text:
means any disposition by an act between living
          persons that is required to be executed by the owner of the land disposed of, and
          includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
a transfer, agreement of sale, assignment of an agreement for sale, lease or
            other instrument intended to convey or transfer any interest in land,

a mortgage or encumbrance intended to charge land with the payment of money, and
            required to be so executed,
a devise or other disposition made by will, and

a mortgage by deposit of duplicate indefeasible title or indefeasible title, or
            other mortgage not requiring the execution of any document;

bcl:text.#text:
means an entry made in the register of land titles under
          section 2;

means land or any interest in it entitling the owner
          to possession of it that is registered in the records of the land title office in the name
          of the spouse and on which there is a dwelling occupied by the spouses as their residence,
          or that has been so occupied within the period of one year immediately preceding the date
          of the making of the application under section 2;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is married to another person, or

has lived with another person in a marriage-like relationship for a continuous
            period of at least 2 years.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application for charge under this Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If a spouse or a person's spouse on the person's behalf applies to the registrar
          for an entry on the register that a homestead is subject to this Act the registrar must
          make the entry

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the application is in the prescribed form,

the application is accompanied by an affidavit of the applicant spouse in the
            prescribed form, and

the registrar is satisfied that there has been compliance with this
            Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The application for an entry may be made by a spouse in person or on a person's
          behalf by that person's spouse, solicitor or authorized agent.

The person making the application must reside in British Columbia and must be
          19 years or older.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When disposition without consent of spouse is void

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If an entry has been made on the register under section 2, a disposition of the
          homestead by a spouse during the life of that spouse if the interest of that spouse must
          or may vest in any other person at any time during the life of that spouse, or during the
          life of the spouse of that spouse living at the date of the disposition, is void for all
          purposes unless made with the written consent of the spouse on whose behalf the entry is
          made.

A conveyance designed to avoid the right given by this Act has no
          effect.

bcl:text.#text:
If an entry has been made on the title under section 2,
          section
          162 (1) of the  applies to the devolution of the
          homestead.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Despite any testamentary disposition or rule of law and subject to the liability
          of the land comprising the homestead for foreclosure or the payment of debts, a personal
          representative holds the homestead in trust for an estate for the life of the surviving
          spouse.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
If at the time of death of a spouse, the surviving spouse is living apart from the
        deceased spouse under circumstances disentitling the surviving spouse to support, alimony or
        maintenance, no life estate vests in the surviving spouse and the surviving spouse does not
        take any benefit under this Act.
This Act ceases to apply when the spouses have

bcl:text.#text:
resolved the ownership or division of the homestead by an agreement or order made
          under the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Any consent required for a disposition during the lifetime of a spouse that takes
          effect during the lifetime of that spouse, of a homestead under this Act must be produced
          and filed in the land title office with the instrument by which the disposition is
          effected.

The consent may be embodied in or endorsed on the instrument effecting the
          disposition.

The execution of a disposition referred to in subsection (1) by the spouse on
          whose behalf the entry is made constitutes a consent under this Act.

On application by petition and on being satisfied that it is fair and reasonable
          under the circumstances to do so, the Supreme Court may dispense with the consent of a
          spouse, on whose behalf an entry is made, to a proposed disposition if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the spouse on whose behalf the entry is made

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: has not since the marriage lived in British Columbia, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the whereabouts of the spouse referred to in paragraph (b) is
            unknown.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
An order under subsection (1) may be made on terms and conditions as to
          payment into court or otherwise that the court in the circumstances thinks
          proper.

If the court is satisfied that the spouse on whose behalf the entry is made has
          not, since the marriage, lived in British Columbia or the whereabouts of that spouse is
          unknown, it may dispense with the giving of notice of the application for the order or
          give other directions as to service of the notice.

If the spouse on whose behalf entry is made is a mentally disordered person or
          person of unsound mind, notice of an application to dispense with the consent of that
          spouse must be served in the manner provided by the rules of the Supreme Court for the
          service of writs on those persons.

bcl:text.#text:
On the order being filed with the registrar at the proper land title office, and
          on compliance with the , the registrar must
          register the transfer.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Presumption of consent from participation in sale

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If the spouse on whose behalf an entry is made has executed a contract for sale of
          the homestead, joined in the execution of it with the other spouse or given written
          consent to the execution of it, and the consideration under the contract has been totally
          or partly performed by the purchaser, the spouse on whose behalf the entry was made is, in
          the absence of fraud on the part of the purchaser, deemed to have consented to the sale in
          accordance with this Act.

bcl:text.#text:
If a subsequent disposition by way of transfer of the homestead is presented for
          registration under the , the consent previously
          given or the agreement executed, if produced and filed with the registrar, is sufficient
          for the purposes of this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Abandonment by spouse of benefits and privileges

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A homestead or part of a homestead and the benefits and privileges conferred on
          the spouse on whose behalf an entry is made under this Act in respect of the homestead or
          any part of it may be abandoned by that spouse by a document, in the prescribed form,
          abandoning the homestead rights.

The registrar must cancel the entry on receiving an application in the form
          prescribed for applying for the cancellation of an entry, accompanied by the document
          referred to in subsection (1).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote:
Cancellation on protected spouse predeceasing other
        spouse
bcl:section.bcl:text:
On application in the form prescribed for applying for the cancellation of an entry,
        accompanied by evidence satisfactory to the registrar that the spouse on whose behalf the
        entry was made has died, or that a decree has been pronounced dissolving or annulling the
        marriage of the spouse on whose behalf an entry was made to the spouse in whose name the
        homestead is registered, the registrar must cancel the entry.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote:
Spouse may be required to show why entry should not be
        discharged

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A spouse or the personal representative of the spouse may by summons call on the
          other spouse to attend before a court of competent jurisdiction to show cause why an entry
          should not be discharged if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
an entry under section 2 has been made on the register,
            and

the spouse in whose name the homestead is registered, or that spouse's personal
            representative, claims

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: that the land affected or a part of it is not a homestead, or
that the entry for any other reason should not have been made.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
On proof that the spouse has been summoned as required by subsection (1),
          and on evidence that the court may require, the court may make an order that it considers
          appropriate in the circumstances.

bcl:text.#text:
If a person is dissatisfied with a decision of the registrar under this Act, that
        person may, within 21 days of the receipt of notice of the decision, appeal to the Supreme
        Court in a summary way by petition, and section 309 of the  applies to the appeal.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may prescribe forms for the purposes of this
        Act.
